Graphical abstract Addressing the shuttle effect of soluble sodium polysulfides through catalytic improvements is crucial. In this work, we introduce a novel strategy by modulating the electronic structure of Mo2C via anti-bonding orbitals occupancy, improving polysulfide adsorption and sulfur redox kinetics. The DFT calculations demonstrate that Ni, as an electron donor, shifts d-band center of Mo closer to the Fermi level, reducing π*-orbital electron occupation, thus enhancing polysulfide bonding. This unique approach mitigates shuttling effects, leading to significant electrochemical performance enhancements in room-temperature Na-S batteries. Understanding the structure-property relationship and the mechanisms by which catalysts promote polysulfide conversion is crucial for the rational design of room-temperature sodium-sulfur (RT Na-S) battery catalysts. Herein, we systematically investigate Fe-, Co-, and Ni-incorporated Mo2C as catalysts for RT Na-S battery to elucidate the intrinsic correlation between the d band center of Mo in Mo2C and its catalytic activity. Combining experimental and theoretical analysis revealed that Ni-substituted Mo2C elevates the d band center while significantly reducing antibonding orbitals (π*) occupancy compared to Fe-substituted Mo2C and Co-substituted Mo2C counterparts. This electronic restruction enhances d-p hybridization at the Mo-S interface, which strengthens sodium polysulfides adsorption energy and enhances charge transfer, thereby steering sulfur redox pathways toward thermodynamically favorable configurations. Our findings elucidate the intricate interplay between the electronic structure and catalytic activity of Mo2C, advancing a novel perspective for the rational design of RT Na-S battery catalysts through tailored modulation of antibonding orbital occupancy. Keywords Sodium-sulfur battery Electronic structure Catalytic activity d band center d-p hybridization 1 Introduction Room-temperature sodium-sulfur (RT Na-S) battery is recognized as a promising next-generation energy storage technology due to the abundant natural reserves of sodium and sulfur, high theoretical energy density (∼350 Wh kg−1), low-cost, and less of a safety concern [1–3]. Nevertheless, the sulfur to sodium polysulfides (NaPSs, Na2S n , 0 ≤ n ≤ 8) conversion reaction induces a severe volume expansion [4,5], while the soluble NaPSs shuttle effect leads to rapid capacity decay, low Coulombic efficiency, and increased polarization during cycling, significantly hindering their practical deployment [6,7]. Rational design of advanced sulfur host materials is critical to overcoming these challenges. Porous carbon materials including carbon nanotube [8], carbon polyhedrons [9], and carbon nanofibers [10] have been widely adopted as sulfur hosts to enhance electrical conductivity and accommodate volumetric strain during charge/discharge. Nevertheless, the weak interaction between porous carbon materials and polysulfides fails to sufficiently suppress the shuttle effect. Recent advances highlight that embedding catalytic sites (e.g., metal sulfides, phosphides, oxides, or carbides) within porous carbon materials can effectively anchor NaPSs and regulate sulfur redox kinetics [11–14]. Transition metal carbides (TMCs), a critical class of catalytic materials, have attracted significant attention because of their unique physical and chemical properties. Among these, molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) has emerged as a prominent candidate for catalytic and energy storage applications, owing to its electrical conductivity (∼1.02 × 104 S m−1) that facilitates rapid electron transfer during redox reactions [15–18]. For example, Yu’s group reported Mo2C nanoparticles embedded in hierarchically hollow porous carbon polyhedrons as the S host material (HPC/Mo2C) for RT Na-S battery [17]. The S@HPC/Mo2C cathode displays a high reversible capacity (1098 mAh g−1 after 120 cycles at 0.2 A g−1) and excellent rate performance (483 mAh g−1 at 10.0 A g−1). Although the application of Mo2C-based materials has promoted the progress of RT Na-S battery, the relationships between the electronic structure of Mo2C and its catalytic behaviors toward soluble NaPSs remain unclear. The catalytic activity of Mo2C is intrinsically linked to its electronic configuration, particularly the d-band center (ɛd ), which governs antibonding orbital occupancy. The anti-bonding orbital occupation plays a vital role in determining the stability and reactivity of polysulfide intermediates. When electrons occupy anti-bonding orbitals, bonds are weakened, leading to issues like the dissolution of polysulfides in the electrolyte and reduced cycle stability. Therefore, understanding and controlling anti-bonding orbital occupation is essential to improving the overall performance of RT Na-S battery [19,20]. However, there has been a lack of in-depth research into the modulation of the antibonding orbital occupation in Mo2C by constructing heterostructures with other materials rather than doping. Such insights are crucial for the development of highly efficient catalysts used in the RT Na-S battery. Notably, group VIII transition metals (Fe, Co, and Ni), with unpaired 3d electrons, can activate the redox reactions and impact the structural rearrangement of adjacent Mo sites [21]. Their higher electron density compared to Mo reduces the occupancy of antibonding orbitals of Mo while enriching d-orbital electron density, thereby strengthening NaPSs adsorption and lowering redox energy barriers [22,23]. However, the precise mechanisms by which Fe/Co/Ni incorporation regulates orbital hybridization (d-p interactions) and interfacial charge transfer in Mo2C remain unresolved, highlighting the need for atomic-level electronic structure analysis. Confident in the hypothesis that integrating Fe, Co, and Ni with Mo2C to construct heterostructures can effectively modulate the d band center of Mo. To our knowledge, this is the first comprehensive study to explore the relationship between the d band center of Mo in Mo2C and the adsorption and catalytic behavior of soluble NaPSs in RT Na-S battery. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the Ni-substituted Mo2C elevates the d band center of Mo in Mo2C, reducing antibonding orbital (π*) electron occupancy compared to Fe- and Co-substituted counterparts. This reduction mitigates the polysulfide shuttle effect by strengthening Mo–S bonds at the electrode interface. In the case of Fe/Mo2C@C, the d band center increases, leading to higher antibonding orbital occupancy and weakened polysulfide binding. Conversely, Co/Mo2C@C exhibits a decreased d band center, which further increases antibonding occupancy and consequently reduces the adsorption of NaPSs. This research offers valuable insights into the relationship between the catalytic behavior of Mo in Mo2C and d band center, which is pivotal for the rational development of highly active catalysts for RT Na-S battery. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of materials 2.1.1 Synthesis of X/Mo-Glycerate solid spheres precursor (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) 0.028 mmol of Fe(NO3)3 ∙ 9H2O and 0.25 mmol of MoO2(acac)2, with a Mo: Co molar ratio of 9:1, were dissolved in a mixed solution containing 8 mL of glycerol and 40 mL of isopropanol. After ultrasonic treatment for 10 min and stirring for an additional 30 min, the resulting solution was transferred to an 80 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the product was separated by centrifugation and washed several times with ethanol. The preparations of Co/Mo-glycerate and Ni/Mo-glycerate follow the same procedure as Fe/Mo-glycerate, except that 0.028 mmol of Co(NO3)2 ∙ 6H2O or 0.028 mmol of Ni(NO3)2 ∙ 6H2O was used in place of Fe(NO3)3 ∙ 9H2O. 2.1.2 Synthesis of X/Mo-G@ZIF-8 (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) Typically, 100 mL of a CH3OH solution containing 1 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, K-30) and 200 mg of the as-prepared Fe/Mo-G precursor was first treated with ultrasound for 30 min. Subsequently, 2.19 g of Zn(NO3)2 ∙ 6H2O was added to the solution and stirred vigorously for another 2 h. The same procedure was applied to the Co/Mo-G precursor and Ni/Mo-G precursor. Then, 100 mL of a CH3OH solution containing 1 g of 2-methylimidazole was slowly added to the mixed methanol solution over 20 min. After vigorous agitation for 30 min, the Fe/Mo-G@ZIF-8 precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed with CH3OH at least five times, and then dried at 60 °C for 12 h. The preparations of Co/Mo-G@ZIF-8 and Ni/Mo-G@ZIF-8 follow the same procedure as that of Fe/Mo-G@ZIF-8, except that the precursors of Co/Mo-G@ZIF-8 and Ni/Mo-G@ZIF-8 were used, respectively. 2.1.3 Synthesis of X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) The Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C composites were obtained by annealing Fe/Mo-G@ZIF-8, Co/Mo-G@ZIF-8, and Ni/Mo-G@ZIF-8, respectively, under an Ar atmosphere for 3 h at 950 °C with a temperature ramp rate of 2 °C min−1. 2.1.4 Synthesis of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) Fe/Mo2C@C (or Co/Mo2C@C or Ni/Mo2C@C) and sulfur (1:2) were mixed and ground for 10 min. The mixture was then heated at 155 °C for 12 h, followed by further heating at 300 °C for 2 h in a sealed quartz tube to obtain S/Fe/Mo2C@C, S/Co/Mo2C@C, and S/Ni/Mo2C@C. 2.2 Material characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer in the 2θ range from 10° to 80°. The morphologies of the synthesized samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, HITACHI SU8010). The detailed structural characteristics of the samples were recorded using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Talos F200X, USA) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using a PHI5000 Versa Probe III XPS with an Al K α excitation source. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET, ASAP 2020 PLUS HD88) surface area and pore size distributions were obtained from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was employed to calculate the carbon content of the samples using a 600 SDT, over a temperature range from room temperature to 900 °C in air. Raman spectra were recorded using a dispersive Raman microscope (XPLORA PLUS) with a 532 nm excitation wavelength. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical measurements of the samples were carried out using CR2025 coin-type cells assembled in an Ar-filled glovebox. The working electrodes were prepared by thoroughly blending the active material, carbon black, and carboxymethylcellulose sodium salt (CMC) binder in a weight ratio of 7:2:1, using distilled water as the solvent. The slurry was evenly applied to aluminum foil and subsequently dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. In the standard testing procedure, the composite mass loading of each electrode was precisely maintained at 1.5 mg cm−2. Additionally, tests with higher mass loadings were performed, with the composite mass loading reaching up to 4 mg cm−2. In the standard testing procedure, the sulfur content in the electrode was 44.5%, and the sulfur content in the composite was 63.5%. The electrolyte solution consisted of 1 M NaClO4 dissolved in a mixed solution of propylene carbonate (PC) and ethylene carbonate (EC) (PC: EC = 1:1), with 5 wt% fluoroethylene carbonates (FEC) as the additive. Sodium foil was used for both the reference and counter electrodes, while a glass fiber (Whatman GF/D) membrane was chosen as the separator. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were conducted over a voltage range of 0.8–2.8 V, with scan rates varying from 0.1 to 1.0 mV s−1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed at ambient temperature, covering a frequency range from 0.01 to 100 kHz, using a CHI 660D electrochemical workstation. After aging for over 12 h, charge-discharge tests were conducted within a cut-off potential range of 0.8–2.8 V using the LAND battery program-controlled test system. 2.4 Synthesis of Na2S6 solution and adsorption test The Na2S6 solution was prepared by dissolving Na2S and S in a molar ratio of 1:5 in a 1:1 vol mixture of EC and PC at 80 °C, allowing it to react overnight. Then, 10 mg of Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C were immersed in 2 mL of the Na2S6 solution. After a resting period of 12 h, a photograph documenting the visible adsorption process was captured, and the residual polysulfide concentration in the solution was measured using ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectroscopy. 2.5 Symmetric cell test To evaluate the catalytic activity of Ni/Mo2C@C in the transformation of polysulfides, CR2025-type coin symmetric cells were fabricated with the as-prepared Ni/Mo2C@C acting as both the cathode and anode, containing 60 μL of Na2S6 (0.1 M) electrolyte. The 0.1 M Na2S6 solution was prepared by dissolving Na2S and sublimed sulfur at a molar ratio of 1:6 into an EC and PC (1:1 by volume) solution, which served as the electrolyte. Symmetric batteries were then assembled. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements of the assembled symmetric batteries were conducted within a voltage window of −1.0 to 1.0 V at various scan rates. For comparison, additional symmetric batteries were assembled using the same approach with identical Fe/Mo2C@C or Ni/Mo2C@C electrodes. 2.6 Na2S nucleation test The precipitation capacities of Na2S on different materials were tested using CR2025-type coin batteries, with a GF/D membrane as the separator and commercial sodium as the anode. The catholyte, a 0.2 M Na2S6 solution, was prepared by dissolving Na2S and sublimed sulfur in an EC/PC mixture at a molar ratio of 1:6. Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C materials were used as cathodes, with Na metal foil as the anode and glass fiber as the separator. A total of 30 μL of Na2S6 was gradually dispensed onto the cathodes, while 80 μL of Na2S6-free electrolyte was added to the anode compartment. The batteries were discharged galvanostatically to 1.25 V and then maintained at a potentiostatic voltage of 1.2 V until the current dropped below 10−5 A. The nucleation/growth rate of Na2S was evaluated by the charge collected, in accordance with Faraday’s law. 2.7 Theoretical calculation DFT calculations were performed using Quantum Espresso 7.0 (QE7.0) with the projector-augmented-wave method [24,25]. The generalized gradient approximation of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was employed as the exchange-correlation functional [26]. The Brillouin zone was sampled with 2 × 2 × 1 k-points for surface calculations. The cutoff energy was set to 500 eV, and structure relaxation was carried out until the energy and force convergence criteria reached 1 × 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV Å−1, respectively. A vacuum layer of 15 Å was added to prevent interactions between periodic structures of the surface models. Van der Waals (vdW) interactions were corrected using the zero-damping DFT-D3 method of Grimme [27]. The adsorption energy (ΔE ads) of Na x S y adsorption on surface is defined as Δ E a d s = E ( ∗ N a x S y ) - E ( ∗ ) - E ( N a x S y ) where E(*Na x S y ) and E(*) are the total energy of surface systems with and without Na x S y , respectively, and E(Na x S y ) is the energy of an isolated Na x S y . According to this definition, negative adsorption energy suggests that the adsorption process is exothermic and the adsorption system is thermodynamically stable. Contrarily, a positive value corresponds to an endothermic and unstable adsorption. The Gibbs free energy was calculated as: ΔG = ΔE + ΔE ZPE − TΔS. Where the ΔE, ΔE ZPE, and ΔS represent the electronic energy, zero-point energy, and entropy difference between products and reactants, respectively. The zero-point energies and entropies of the absorbed intermediate products were calculated using the VASPKIT software [28]. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis process of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). For Ni/Mo2C@C, the Ni/Mo-glycerate (Ni/Mo-G) solid sphere precursor, with a size of 2 μm and a smooth surface (Fig. S1c), was prepared by a conventional solvothermal method with slight modifications. Subsequently, a zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanoparticle layer was uniformly grown on the surface of the Ni/Mo-G via electrostatic interactions between OH− and Zn2+, followed by a reaction with 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm), leading to the formation of the core-shell Ni/Mo-G@ZIF-8 composite, as shown in Fig. S2(c). The XRD pattern reveals the co-existence of Ni/Mo-G and ZIF-8 phases (Fig. S3c). For comparison, the Fe/Mo-G solid sphere precursor (Fig. S1a) and Co/Mo-G solid sphere precursor (Fig. S1b), both with similar morphologies to the Ni/Mo-G solid sphere precursor, were also synthesized. The core-shell structures of Fe/Mo-G@ZIF-8 (Fig. S2a) and Co/Mo-G@ZIF-8 (Fig. S2b) were obtained after coating with ZIF-8, and their XRD patterns show the co-existence of Fe/Mo-G, Co/Mo-G, and ZIF-8 phases, as shown in Fig. S3(a and b), respectively. During the carbonization process, the organic ligands in ZIF-8 transform into micro/mesoporous carbon layers, which enhance the electrical conductivity of sulfur and inhibit the polysulfide shuttle process. By tuning the d-band center of Mo2C, we modulate the antibonding orbital occupation of Mo to enhance the electronic structure and catalytic performance. With Ni incorporation, the d-band center of Mo2C shifts most positively compared to Fe and Co, optimizing the adsorption strength for NaPSs (Fig. 1b). Magnetic field-dependent measurements of Ni@C and Ni/Mo2C@C at room temperature confirm strong Ni/Mo2C interactions, as indicated by the S-type ferromagnetic hysteresis loops (Fig. 1c) [29]. Ni/Mo2C@C shows a specific saturation magnetization (M s) of 0.00023 emu g−1, significantly lower than Ni@C (0.01781 emu g−1), suggesting electron redistribution and the formation of abundant heterostructure interfaces that generate a built-in electric field, enhancing electron/ion transport. The Ni/Mo2C heterostructure not only provides strong NaPS adsorption and catalytic activity but also lowers the NaPS diffusion energy barrier. The optimized electronic structure reduces antibonding orbital occupation, increases electrical conductivity, further influences charge transfer, and promotes orbital hybridization with NaPSs, thereby improving RT Na-S battery reaction kinetics (Fig. 1d–f). The morphology of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) was observed by using SEM and TEM. The SEM image of S/Ni/Mo2C@C exhibits an average diameter of 3–5 μm (Fig. 2 a). Notably, the morphological features of S/Fe/Mo2C@C (Fig. 2b) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (Fig. 2c) are similar to those of S/Ni/Mo2C@C. The TEM image of S/Ni/Mo2C@C in Fig. 2(d) shows that the thickness of the carbon shell is around 15 nm, which can effectively physically confine active sulfur inside of micro/mesoporous structures, accommodating the volume change of S during the charge/discharge process. Similarly, the core-shell structure can also be observed in S/Fe/Mo2C@C (Fig. 2e) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (Fig. 2f). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images in Fig. 2(g–i) clearly reveal two different crystal planes in contact with their interfaces. The lattice fringe of 2.3 Å corresponds to the (101) plane of Mo2C, while another crystal plane with an interlayer distance of 2 Å represents the (111) plane of the Ni phase (Fig. 2g). Analogously, the twinborn interfaces of Co (111) and Mo2C (101) crystals and Fe (110) and Mo2C (101) crystals are shown in Fig. 2(h and i), respectively, indicating that the heterostructure interfaces were successfully formed. These heterostructure interfaces can provide extra active sites to adsorb soluble NaPSs and accelerate the transformation of NaPSs. Furthermore, the energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping shows that Ni, Mo, C, and S elements are uniformly distributed in Ni/Mo2C@C, as shown in Fig. 2(j). The results in Fig. 2(k and l) confirm the same distribution as shown in Fig. 2(j). The XRD patterns of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) composites are shown in Fig. 3 (a). The diffraction profiles of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) indicate that β-Mo2C (JCPDF No. 35-0787) is the dominant phase, and the broad peak at around 25° corresponds to the (002) diffraction of carbon. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, obtained using the BET method, were employed to investigate the surface areas and porous structures of X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) composites, as illustrated in Fig. 3(b). All prepared samples exhibit the coexistence of micro/mesopores in the porous carbon shell. The BET surface areas of Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C are 440.3, 447.5, and 506.0 m2 g−1, respectively. The larger surface area of Ni/Mo2C@C effectively enhances the sulfur loading and alleviates the volume expansion of S during the cycling process. The sulfur content in X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) composites is ∼60 wt% (Fig. 3c). Raman spectra show that the X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) composites present three prominent peaks at 1350 and 1580 cm−1, attributed to the disorder-induced D band and graphitic G band, respectively (Fig. S4). In general, the lower value of I D/I G indicates a higher degree of graphitization, which can enhance the electrical conductivity. Compared with Fe/Mo2C@C and Co/Mo2C@C composites, the Ni/Mo2C@C composite has a lower I D/I G ratio. In addition, the chemical composition and elemental valence states of the S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) composites were investigated by usingXPS. For the S/Ni/Mo2C@C composite, the XPS survey spectrum (Fig. S5) detects Ni, Mo, C, and S elements. The C 1s spectrum of all three composites can be divided into five peaks at 283.7, 284.2, 285.2, 286.1, and 287.8 eV, ascribed to the C–Mo, C–C/C=C, C–N, C–O, and O–C=O, respectively (Fig. S6a–c) [30]. As shown in Fig. S7, the high-resolution S 2p spectrum of S/Ni/Mo2C@C displays three characteristic peaks of sulfur, corresponding to S 2p 3/2 (163.6 eV), S 2p 1/2 (164.8 eV), and sulfate, respectively [31]. The high-resolution Fe 2p spectrum of S/Fe-Mo2C@C is shown in Fig. S8(a). The peaks at 706.3 and 720.2 eV corresponded to metallic Fe species [32]. Similarly, as presented in the Co 2p spectrum (Fig. S8b) of S/Co/Mo2C@C, two dominant peaks at 780.2 and 796.5 eV are ascribed to metallic Co species [33]. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. S8c) of S/Ni/Mo2C@C is deconvoluted into six peaks, which are attributed to metallic Ni (853.6/870.7 eV), oxidized Ni species (859/874 eV), and satellite peaks (866/879 eV) [32]. The Mo 3d high-resolution XPS spectrum of S/Ni/Mo2C@C, compared with S/Fe/Mo2C@C and S/Co/Mo2C@C in Fig. 3(d), shows two distinct peaks at 231.8 and 228.6 eV, which correspond to the 3d 3/2 and 3d 5/2 of Mo2+, respectively, providing evidence for the formation of Mo2C. Additionally, states of Mo4+ and Mo6+ are also observed, which can be attributed to the inevitable surface oxidation of Mo2C [4]. Compared to S/Co/Mo2C@C, an obvious upshift (0.4 eV) of the Mo 3d peaks can be observed in S/Ni/Mo2C@C, indicating that more electrons are transferred from metal Ni to Mo, thereby improving the catalytic activity of Mo2C. Furthermore, a slight upshift (0.2 eV) of the Mo 3d peaks is observed for S/Fe/Mo2C@C compared to S/Co/Mo2C@C, likely due to the introduction of metal Fe, which decreases the electron density on Mo. These results indicate that the electronic structure of Mo can be optimized by constructing heterostructures with transition metals. To explore the adsorbing ability of Mo2C when coupled with transition metals (Fe, Co, and Ni) toward Na2S6, visible adsorption tests and UV-vis spectra were carried out. As shown in the inset of Fig. 3(e), the Na2S6 solutions containing Fe/Mo2C@C and Ni/Mo2C@C become colorless, indicating a strong interaction between Fe/Mo2C@C, Ni/Mo2C@C and Na2S6, while the Na2S6 solution with Co/Mo2C@C remains pale yellow. Besides, UV-vis adsorption spectra were used to measure the amount of Na2S6 in the solution (Fig. 3e). The solutions after soaking Ni/Mo2C@C reveal a weaker signal compared to those with Co/Mo2C@C and Fe/Mo2C@C, confirming that Ni/Mo2C@C has the strongest attraction to Na2S6. To further investigate the chemical interactions between the three samples and Na2S6, XPS analysis was performed. In the high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s (Fig. S9a–c), a new peak at 286.7 eV, attributed to the C–S bond, appears after Na2S6 adsorption, suggesting a strong chemical affinity between the porous carbon and Na2S6. Compared to the pristine Fe/Mo2C@C, the characteristic Fe 2p peaks shift by 1.0 eV toward lower binding energy after Na2S6 adsorption (Fig. S10a). However, XPS peaks of Co 2p remain unchanged before and after adsorption (Fig. S10b), indicating that the metallic cobalt has a weaker adsorption effect on polysulfides. In contrast, for Ni/Mo2C@C, the characteristic Ni 2p peaks shift by 1.6 eV toward lower binding energy after Na2S6 adsorption (Fig. S10c). The S 2p peaks of Na2S6 adsorbed on the three samples display a positive shift to higher binding energy (Fig. 3f). Additionally, a new peak at 160.7 eV is observed, which is attributed to S–Mo bond and the intensity of S–Mo peak is the highest in Ni/Mo2C@C after soaking in Na2S6 solution, implying the strongest chemical interaction between Na2S6 and Ni/Mo2C@C. The XPS spectra of Mo 3d for Fe/Mo2C@C-Na2S6, Co/Mo2C@C-Na2S6, and Ni/Mo2C@C-Na2S6 are presented in Fig. 3(g–i), respectively. Compared to the Mo 3d spectrum of pristine powder, a new Mo–S bond appears in the Ni/Mo2C@C-Na2S6, indicating that Mo2C achieves chemical adsorption by forming Mo–S bonding, which helps restrain the polysulfides shuttling. Moreover, the characteristic peaks of Mo–C shift towards lower binding energy due to the transfer of electrons from Na2S6 to Mo atoms, verifying the strong binding affinity between Mo2C and Na2S6 [34]. In summary, these results demonstrate that the electron density of Mo can be influenced by coupling with transition metals (Fe, Co, and Ni), which not only facilitates the chemical attachment of NaPSs and enhances catalytic activity for suppressing the shuttle effect, but also boosts the interfacial charge transfer process. The electrochemical performances of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) cathodes were investigated in the voltage window of 0.8–2.8 V. It has been reported that the shuttle effect is more severe in carbonate-based electrolytes than that in ether-based electrolytes [35,36]. Therefore, carbonic ester-based electrolyte is commonly used to enhance the cycle stability of RT Na-S battery. The electrochemical reaction process was initially examined using CV technique. Fig. 4 (a) presents the CV curves of S/Ni/Mo2C@C at 0.1 mV s−1. During the initial cathodic process, two reduction peaks at 2.2 and 1.0 V are attributed to the irreversible reduction of S8 to long-chain Na2S n (4 < n ≤ 8) and the formation of insoluble products Na2S2/Na2S, respectively. In the subsequent cycle, these cathodic peaks shift to 1.68 and 1.1 V, respectively. For the anodic process, two peaks at 1.85 and 2.15 V correspond to the oxidation of Na2S2/Na2S to long-chain Na2S n (4 < n ≤ 8), and then to S8, respectively [37–39]. The CV curves of S/Fe/Mo2C@C (Fig. S11a) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (Fig. S11b) cathodes exhibit similar electrochemical behaviors to those of the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode. Fig. 4(b) presents the galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles of the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode at 0.1 A g−1. The cathodic and anodic plateaus are well aligned with the CV profiles. Compared to the S/Fe/Mo2C@C (Fig. S12a) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (Fig. S12b) cathodes, the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode delivers higher discharge and charge specific capacities of 2290.1 and 1372 mAh g−1, respectively. To explain the reason for the excess discharge capacity, two key observations were made. First, the pristine Ni/Mo2C@C cathode, without sulfur, was discharged to the same voltage, and the result in Fig. S13(a) shows an initial discharge capacity of only 93.2 mAh g−1, indicating that the excess capacity is not primarily due to Na intercalation in Ni/Mo2C@C. Second, the Na 1s XPS spectrum of the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode after the initial discharge was characterized, revealing only Na–F, Na–O, and Na2CO3 peaks, with no evidence of Na metal peaks (Fig. S13b). This suggests that reversible Na metal deposition on the cathode surface can also be excluded. Therefore, the excess discharge capacity is attributed to parasitic reactions. These parasitic reactions between S species and electrolyte solvents lead to the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) layers on the electrode surface. This process, referred to as electrochemical activation, likely involves the exfoliation and breakage of the dilated graphene sheaths around the carbides by sodium ions during activation. This, in turn, enhances the electrocatalytic activity of the particles during cycling [37]. To further investigate the excellent catalytic and adsorption capacity of Ni/Mo2C@C, the rate performance of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) cathodes was evaluated at different current rates (0.1–5 A g−1). As depicted in Fig. 4(c), the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode delivers superior capacity of 1143.9, 1005.2, 855.7, 733.7, 616.51, and 424.0 mAh g−1 at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 A g−1, respectively. When the current density is returned to 0.1 A g−1, it maintains a high reversible capacity of 992.1 mAh g−1, which is significantly higher than that of the S/Fe/Mo2C@C (777.1 mAh g−1) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (693.4 mAh g−1). Furthermore, Fig. 4(d) presents the cycling performance of these three electrodes at 0.2 A g−1. The S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode delivers a higher initial discharge capacity of 2290.1 mAh g−1 than S/Fe/Mo2C@C (1830.6 mAh g−1) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (1427 mAh g−1), demonstrating that Ni/Mo2C@C exhibits strong catalytic activity and adsorption strength. To further confirm this, Fig. 4(e) shows the third CV curve of S/Fe/Mo2C@C, S/Co/Mo2C@C, and S/Ni/Mo2C@C. The current responses of the cathodic and anodic peaks for the cell with S/Ni/Mo2C@C are higher than those for the cells with S/Fe/Mo2C@C and S/Co/Mo2C@C, indicating that Ni/Mo2C@C has superior catalytic capabilities for polysulfides conversion compared to Fe/Mo2C@C and Co/Mo2C@C. In addition, the galvanostatic charge-discharge curves of S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) cathodes are shown in Fig. 4(f). The S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode exhibits the lowest potential hysteresis (ΔV = 0.47 V) compared to S/Fe/Mo2C@C (0.49 V) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (0.54 V), demonstrating that Ni/Mo2C @C can reduce electrochemical polarization and efficiently enhance the reaction kinetics of Na-S. As shown in Fig. S14, after 100 cycles, the capacities of S/Ni@C and S/Mo2C@C electrodes remained at 356 and 353 mAh g−1, respectively. In contrast, the S/Ni/Mo2C@C electrodes achieved a significantly higher capacity of 860 mAh g−1. These results indicate that the electronic structure of Mo2C can be optimized by incorporating Ni, promoting d-p hybridization between Mo and S atoms, and modifying the potential reaction pathways. Fig. 4(g) presents the charge-discharge curves of the S/Ni/Mo2C@C at various current densities, offering a comprehensive overview of its electrochemical performance. The S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode reveals the lowest voltage polarization than S/Fe/Mo2C@C (Fig. S15a) and S/Co/Mo2C@C (Fig. S15b) cathodes. In addition, the cyclic stability of S/Ni/Mo2C@C with high composite mass loading (6.8 mg cm−2) was also measured (Fig. 4h), corresponding to an electrolyte-to-sulfur (E/S) ratio of 14.9 μL mg−1 and a negative/positive (N/P) areal capacity ratio of 4.2. The S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode still exhibits a specific capacity of 412.2 mAh g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 after 100 cycles and 326.1 mAh g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 after 60 cycles, respectively. Moreover, it delivers a high reversible capacity of 1459.8 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1, retaining 581 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles (Fig. 4i), indicating that Ni/Mo2C@C can efficiently activate and catalyze soluble NaPSs. In comparison, the S/Fe/Mo2C@C and S/Co/Mo2C@C cathodes retain only 440.9 and 388.3 mAh g−1, respectively. Notably, when compared with recently reported sulfur cathode materials, the S/Ni/Mo2C@C composite cathode demonstrates superior rate performance [14,40–48], as shown in Fig. 4(j). Fig. S16(a–c) presents the electrochemical performance of Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C under the same test conditions as RT Na-S battery. The capacity contributions from Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C in the S/Fe/Mo2C@C, S/Co/Mo2C@C, and S/Ni/Mo2C@C are negligible. This plays an important role in evaluating potential structural degradation, phase transitions, or metal loss caused by the presence of polysulfides over extended cycles. Therefore, post-cycling characterization techniques, including XRD and TEM, were carried out. Fig. S17(a) illustrates the XRD patterns of the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode after 10 cycles. The diffraction profiles show that β-Mo2C (JCPDF No. 35-0787) is still present, consistent with the XRD results of the original powder before cycling. To further confirm this, TEM characterization was performed. As shown in Fig. S17(b, c), the Ni-Mo2C heterostructure interface remains intact even after 10 cycles. No significant structural alterations were observed, suggesting that the structure remains stable and may be suitable for use in other metal-based systems. These results have been incorporated into the revised manuscript. Furthermore, the morphological changes of the S/X/Mo2C@C (X = Fe, Co, and Ni) cathodes after 100 cycles were examined using SEM, as shown in Fig. S18(a–c). No significant structural alterations were observed in the S/Fe/Mo2C@C, S/Co/Mo2C@C, and S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathodes after cycling, suggesting that the structure remains stable and is potentially suitable for use in other metal-based systems. To investigate the reaction kinetics of NaPSs process, the CV curves of S/Fe/Mo2C@C, S/Co/Mo2C@C, and S/Ni/Mo2C@C were recorded at different scanning rates ranging from 0.1 to 1 mV s−1, as shown in Fig. 5 (a–c) and Fig. S19(a–c). Compared with S/Fe/Mo2C@C and S/Co/Mo2C@C, the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode shows smaller potential variations in peaks 1, 2, and 3 as the scan rates increase, indicating that Ni/Mo2C@C significantly enhances both electronic conductivity and the reaction kinetics. Furthermore, EIS was performed to explore the interfacial charge transfer kinetics of the S/X/Mo2C@C (Fe, Co, and Ni) cathodes (Fig. 5d). In EIS Nyquist plots, all diagrams consist of a high-frequency semicircle and a low-frequency straight line. R Ohm, R SEI, R ct, and Z w represent Ohmic resistance, SEI resistance, charge transfer resistance, and Warburg impedance, respectively [49]. Notably, the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode exhibits the lowest R ct and Z w compared to S/Fe/Mo2C@C and S/Co/Mo2C@C, indicating a faster diffusion of Na+ in the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode (Fig. 5e). Symmetric cells were tested to investigate catalytic activity of Ni/Mo2C@C in the transformation of polysulfides. The Ni/Mo2C@C cathode shows the highest current response compared to Fe/Mo2C@C and Co/Mo2C@C (Fig. 5f), demonstrating that Ni/Mo2C@C possesses superior catalytic capability for polysulfides conversion. Besides, the precipitation experiments were performed to confirm the catalytic kinetics of Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C toward NaPSs, as illustrated in Fig. 5(g–i). The Ni/Mo2C@C cathode exhibits the highest current density and the fastest response time (104 mAh g−1 at 104 s) compared to Fe/Mo2C@C (25.8 mAh g−1 at 1200 s) and Co/Mo2C@C (28.9 mAh g−1 at 250 s). These results suggest that the electron structure of the Mo atom can be optimized by the transition metal Ni, accelerating electron transport and Na+ diffusion. As a result, this optimizes the behavior of NaPSs by expanding the electroactive microdomains and improving the distribution of NaPSs during the sulfur redox catalysis process. To study the catalytic mechanism of the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode, the ex-situ XRD, ex-situ Raman spectra, and ex-situ XPS measurements were conducted during cycling. As shown in Fig. 6 (a and b), the characteristic peaks of S8 (JCPDS No. 08-0247) gradually disappear during the discharge process, while the characteristic peaks of Na2S4 (JCPDS No. 71-0516) appear, indicating that the transition from S8 to long-chain NaPSs. As the discharge continues, the Na2S phase (JCPDS No. 77-2149) also appears. Upon discharging to 0.8 V, only the characteristic peaks of Na2S remain, and the peaks associated with NaPSs vanish, suggesting the complete conversion of long-chain NaPSs to Na2S [31]. During the charging process, Na2S gradually converts back to Na2S4 and long-chain NaPSs, demonstrating that Ni/Mo2C@C can effectively catalyze reversible electrochemical reactions. In the second discharging process, the discharged products are similar to those in the first cycle, confirming the excellent electrochemical reversibility. Notably, the characteristic peaks of Mo2C (JCPDS No. 35-0787) remain almost unchanged during the whole reaction process, indicating the excellent stability of the Ni/Mo2C@C heterostructure. Fig. 6(c and d) displays the ex-situ Raman spectra of S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode at different voltage states. A new peak at 390 cm−1 after discharging to 1.7 V indicates the formation of Na2S6. When the electrode discharges further to 1.45 V, a new peak at 449 cm−1 is observed, corresponding to the reduction of Na2S4 [14]. Upon discharging to 0.8 V, a new peak at 433 cm−1 appears, suggesting the reduction of Na2S4 to Na2S [50]. Moreover, the ex-situ XPS analysis of the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode at different voltage states further confirms the bidirectional catalysis mechanism. In the discharge process (Fig. 6e), when discharged to 1.45 V, four peaks at 158.8/159.9 and 160.8/162.1 eV are detected, which can be attributed to Na2S and Na2S n (2 < n ≤ 4), respectively [14,51–53]. The presence of the Na2S peak indicates that sulfur is directly transformed to NaPSs (Na2S n , 2 < n ≤ 4), while the formation of soluble NaPSs is restrained [54]. With the gradual discharge to 1.0 V, the peak intensities of Na2S strengthen, indicating the transformation of short-chain NaPSs (Na2S n , 2 < n ≤ 4) into Na2S2. Simultaneously, two new peaks at 162.3/163.0 eV appear, corresponding to Na2S2. When fully discharged to 0.8 V, the peaks of Na2S become distinctively more prominent, and the peak intensities of Na2S n (2 < n ≤ 4) continuously decrease. For comparison, S/Fe/Mo2C@C and S/Co/Mo2C@C electrodes were also tested by ex-situ XPS when discharged to 0.8 V. As shown in Fig. 6(e), the peaks of Na2S n (2 < n ≤ 4) and S are still noticeable, indicating that the catalytic activity of Fe/Mo2C@C and Co/Mo2C@C toward NaPSs is less efficient at this stage. In the charge process (Fig. 6f), the peaks of Na2S4 reappeare at 1.75 V, suggesting the conversion of Na2S to long-chain NaPSs. When charged to 2.8 V, the peaks assigned to S8 are dominant, accompanied by a small amount of Na2S4, although the peak intensity is relatively low. However, the S/Fe/Mo2C@C and S/Co/Mo2C@C electrodes exhibit higher characteristic peak intensities for Na2S2 and Na2S4 than S/Ni/Mo2C@C when charged to 1.75 V (Fig. 6f). To further confirm the strong catalytic activity of Ni/Mo2C@C, beaker-type Na-S cells were assembled and analyzed using a dedicated optically transparent glass cell. In the S/Co/Mo2C@C cell, the electrolyte changed slightly from colorless to pale yellow after 48 h of discharge, indicating that the weak interaction between polysulfides and Co/Mo2C@C, coupled with the sluggish redox kinetics of soluble polysulfides, resulted in a severe shuttle effect (Fig. 6g). In contrast, no obvious color change is observed for the S/Ni/Mo2C@C electrode. This provides strong visual evidence that the Ni/Mo2C@C host effectively accelerates the conversion of NaPSs and prevents the dissolution of long-chain NaPSs into the electrolyte, achieving selective and catalytic sulfur conversion during battery cycling. These results are consistent with the findings from the adsorption experiment and UV-vis adsorption spectra, further confirming that Ni/Mo2C@C accelerates redox kinetics and strengthens the trapping capability for NaPSs. The Mo2C surface, though catalytically active, exhibits a different reactivity profile compared to disulfide electrocatalysts typically associated with gelation phenomena. In our study, we did not observe significant electrolyte gelation or substantial changes in electrolyte viscosity during testing [55]. Systematic DFT calculations were conducted to assess the impact of antibonding orbital occupation on the capture affinity and catalytic activity of Mo2C. The projected density of states (PDOS) for Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C reveals the electronic structure modulation of Mo2C. According to the Hammer-Nørskov d-band theory, the antibonding orbital is elevated toward the Fermi level as the d-band center shifts upward, which reduces the likelihood of electrons occupying the antibonding orbital [56–58]. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), the gradual increase in the d-band center of Co/Mo2C@C, Fe/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C suggests a decrease in antibonding orbital filling, which facilitates interfacial electron transfer. The interfacial electron transfer kinetics is crucial factors that influence the redox kinetics of NaPSs, making Ni/Mo2C@C exhibit the highest catalytic conversion activity for NaPSs. Crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis (Fig. 7b) further illustrates the bonding state between Na2S6 and Mo atoms across the three Mo2C variants. The average integrated COHP (iCOHP) provides a measure of interatomic bond strength. A more negative iCOHP value for Ni/Mo2C@C corresponds to the improved orbital hybridization between the Mo d-orbital in Ni/Mo2C@C and the S p-orbital in Na2S6, indicating a stronger Mo–S bond. The iCOHP values are −2.05 for Ni/Mo2C@C, lower than those for Fe/Mo2C@C (−1.99) and Co/Mo2C@C (−1.86), signifying that the antibonding orbitals of Ni/Mo2C@C are occupied by fewer electrons. Stronger bonding interactions between S in Na2S6 and Mo in Mo2C lead to more favorable electron transfer during the redox process, which in turn enhances the kinetics of the redox reactions. Additionally, stronger Mo–S bonding reduces the likelihood of polysulfide intermediates escaping from the surface, thereby preventing their migration during cycling. To further confirm the excellent adsorption capacity of Ni/Mo2C@C, the adsorption energies of Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C toward Na2S6 were calculated (Fig. 7c). The Ni/Mo2C@C shows the strongest adsorption energies (−8.7 eV) for Na2S6 compare to Fe/Mo2C@C (−8.5 eV) and Co/Mo2C@C (−8.2 eV). While the adsorption energies of the three samples are comparable, other factors, including electronic structure, catalytic activity, and ion diffusion capability, are also critical in determining the overall performance of the battery. Charge density difference analysis (Fig. 7d) shows a larger redistribution of charge between Na2S6 and Ni/Mo2C@C compared to Fe/Mo2C@C and Co/Mo2C@C. The yellow and cyan regions represent the depletion and accumulation of electrons, respectively, confirming that NaPSs exhibit stronger bonding with Ni/Mo2C@C, which is consistent with the COHP and adsorption energy results. These results reveal that the Ni/Mo2C@C, with its optimized d band center, can reduce the occupation of antibonding orbitals, thereby strengthening the d-p orbital hybridization between Mo2C and NaPSs. To support this point, the PDOS of Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C with Na2S6 was calculated. After Na2S6 adsorption, the p orbitals of S atoms largely overlap with the dxz / yz and dz 2 orbitals of Mo atoms, resulting in the formation of strong bonding (π and σ) and weaker antibonding (π* and σ*) states, while the dxy and dx 2 − y 2 orbitals are non-bonding and play a lesser role in bonding. According to the Pauli exclusion principle and Hund's rule, electrons will first occupy the lower energy molecular orbitals (σ and π), leaving the antibonding orbitals (π* and σ*) relatively unoccupied. As shown in Fig. 7(g), the S px / y / z orbitals of Na2S6 significantly overlap with the dz 2 and dxz / yz orbitals of Mo in Ni/Mo2C@C, suggesting distinguished orbital-level matching compared with Fe/Mo2C@C (Fig. 7e) and Co/Mo2C@C (Fig. 7f). This further confirms that Ni regulates the electron structure of the Mo central atom to promote d-p orbital hybridization between Mo and S. Additionally, the PDOS showed the arrangement of Mo d orbital energy levels in Fe/Mo2C@C, Co/Mo2C@C, and Ni/Mo2C@C. Compared to Fe/Mo2C@C and Co/Mo2C@C, coupling metal Ni with Mo2C elevates the energy levels of Mo dz 2 and dxz / yz orbitals (Fig. 7h-III). This change leads to lower electronic occupancy in antibonding orbitals and thus strengthens the adsorption for NaPSs. Interestingly, Fe/Mo2C@C shows a similar result to Ni/Mo2C@C, suggesting that Fe/Mo2C@C has an adsorption capacity comparable to Ni/Mo2C@C. Moreover, the energy levels of the dx 2 − y 2 and dx z/ yz orbitals of Mo align with the trend observed for the d-band center, indicating that the elevation of the d-band center of Mo in Ni/Mo2C@C is driven by the upward shift of the Mo dx 2 − y 2 and dxz / yz orbital energy levels. The relative Gibbs free energy calculations for the reduction of S8 to Na2S further confirm the improved reduction selectivity and catalytic efficiency of Ni/Mo2C@C (Fig. 7i). The rate-determining step in the reduction reaction of NaPSs on Ni/Mo2C@C occurs from Na2S8 to Na2S6 (2.2 eV), whereas for Fe/Mo2C@C, it is from Na2S6 to Na2S4 (4.7 eV), and for Co/Mo2C@C, it is from Na2S8 to Na2S6 (2.5 eV). In detail, the first reduction step from S8 to Na2S8 on the three samples is a spontaneous reaction. The subsequent reduction step from Na2S8 to Na2S6 shows that the Gibbs free energy for Fe/Mo2C@C corresponds to a spontaneous exothermic reaction, whereas for Co/Mo2C@C and Ni/Mo2C@C, it is endothermic. This indicates that Fe/Mo2C@C, like Ni/Mo2C@C, exhibits strong adsorption strength toward Na2S6, which is consistent with the results from COHP, adsorption energies, and charge density difference analysis. Notably, the conversion of Ni/Mo2C@C from Na2S8 to Na2S6 delivers the highest positive Gibbs free energy in the whole S conversion reaction process and is considered the rate-determining step in the reduction reaction of NaPSs. As far as we know, the rate-determining step determines the reaction kinetics. The Gibbs free energy value of Ni/Mo2C@C (2.2 eV) is significantly lower than that of Fe/Mo2C@C (4.7 eV) and Co/Mo2C@C (2.5 eV) in the rate-determining step (Na2S8 to Na2S6), demonstrating that Ni/Mo2C@C is more likely to undergo a thermodynamically favorable reduction process, thereby accelerating the reaction kinetics. Moreover, in terms of conversion of long-chain NaPSs, the Gibbs free energy change of Fe/Mo2C@C and Ni/Mo2C@C in the step from Na2S8 to Na2S6 is lower than that of Co/Mo2C@C, suggesting significant suppression of the shuttle effect associated with soluble NaPSs. These analyses underscore the critical role of antibonding orbital occupancy tuning, orbital hybridization, and energy level distribution in the dynamic adsorption and conversion of NaPSs, with Ni/Mo2C@C exhibiting the selectivity and catalytic efficacy for NaPSs. 4 Conclusions The occupation of anti-bonding orbitals is a fundamental factor that influences the performance of RT Na-S battery. Gaining a deeper understanding of how these orbitals impact polysulfides stability and contribute to the shuttling effect offers a pathway for developing more robust RT Na-S battery systems. The d band center of Mo can be effectively regulated by introducing transition metals such as Fe, Co, and Ni into Mo2C. A series of electrochemical investigations and DFT calculations have demonstrated that Ni-substituted Mo2C can influence the electronic density of states near the Fermi level, thereby enhancing the binding strength of polysulfides and reducing their solubility in the electrolyte. Consequently, the S/Ni/Mo2C@C cathode delivers a high specific capacity of 587 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 2 A g−1. This work provides guidelines for designing high-efficiency catalysts by regulating antibonding orbital occupancy in the RT Na-S battery. coredata.dc:description: Understanding the structure-property relationship and the mechanisms by which catalysts promote polysulfide conversion is crucial for the rational design of room-temperature sodium-sulfur (RT Na-S) battery catalysts. Herein, we systematically investigate Fe-, Co-, and Ni-incorporated Mo2C as catalysts for RT Na-S battery to elucidate the intrinsic correlation between the d band center of Mo in Mo2C and its catalytic activity. Combining experimental and theoretical analysis revealed that Ni-substituted Mo2C elevates the d band center while significantly reducing antibonding orbitals (π*) occupancy compared to Fe-substituted Mo2C and Co-substituted Mo2C counterparts. This electronic restruction enhances d-p hybridization at the Mo-S interface, which strengthens sodium polysulfides adsorption energy and enhances charge transfer, thereby steering sulfur redox pathways toward thermodynamically favorable configurations. Our findings elucidate the intricate interplay between the electronic structure and catalytic activity of Mo2C, advancing a novel perspective for the rational design of RT Na-S battery catalysts through tailored modulation of antibonding orbital occupancy.
